Early Access Review
								Recreational activities in virtual reality... a very simple concept, that is much more fun than you might expect! Controls:The controls in Rec Room are very simple and intuitive. Touchpad = Teleport, Trigger = Grab, Menu Button = Menu. That's literally all that you need to know to play this game! Graphics/Animation:The graphics in this game are very cartoonish and simple, But that is NOT a bad thing. The game is very polished and detailed and contains everything you would want from a VR title. The animations in this game are wonderful! They were very well thought out and designed. Everything moves around smoothly, and there are lots of little details that make this game great!Physics:The physics are great, until they are not, but when they are not, there were not supposed to be. All of the games physics work perfectly and smoothly, except for the darts. That's where things get fun. In the main lobby, throwing darts onto objects causes some weird things to occur such as making the object float, or spin. This is all apart of the fun though! The few physics that don't work, don't need to work, and if they did, the game just wouldn't be the same. Multiplayer: This is the main feature of the game, and it is portrayed PERFECTLY! All the small aspects of this game is what makes it so great! Want to join a party with someone? Give them a fist bump! Don't want anyone to hear you sneeze in real life? Put your in-game hand over your mouth to mute your mic! Genius! Most people that play this game tend to be pretty nice. Remember though, this is still the internet, you WILL run into some pretty impolite, no mannered, idiots occasionally. Prepare for explicit language and sexual content. If someone can say it/do it, you can hear it/see it.Customization:You can make your Rec Room avatar look any way that you want it to! There are many different items and accessories including; Shirts, wristbands, glasses, hair bands/bows, gloves, sweatbands, and more! Lots of hair style options are available, and you can change them to any (Natural) hair color. Skin color is also an option!The settings page lets you change just about everything to make the game perfect for you! Resolution too low? Turn it up! Someone talking about something you don't want to hear, or even screaming in their mic? Mute them. Simple. There are TONS of options for voice chat. This even includes a voice changer! Three different options are included for when you want people to hear you. Always On, Push-To-Talk (Grip Button to activate), and Off. Graphics and mic customization are just a few of the settings Rec Room has to offer, so play around with them until they work for you!Games:6 games are currently available to play in Rec Room; Dodgeball, PaintBall, 3D Charades, Disc Golf, Soccer, and Paddle Ball. All of which, are not only as fun as the real thing, but as REAL as the real thing. Each game is totally unique and fun in its own way! None of these games can be played by yourself (while still having fun), they all need two or more people to really complete the experience. (They are multiplayer games in real life after all.) All 6 games allow you to use your mic to communicate with each other. Whether your joking around and having a good time in 3D Charades, or Talking with your team and strategically planning your next Paintball round! Make sure you try out all of the different games, as they are all very fun, unique, and competitive (If you want it to be!).Tips and Tricks:1. You can reorientate your room by squeezing the grip button on both controllers!2. While holding an object with the trigger, you can press the top menu button to lock it in place. Now you no longer have to hold the trigger down! Rec Room is updated almost weekly with new features! It's a free application, which honestly feels like I am scamming the developers of their time and money! Please download this game right now, you waisted time reading this review when you could have been playing the game already! :)9.5/10EDIT: After 50 hours of playtime, I have to change my rating...10/10

								Consider for a moment how life was before celluar phones and broadband internet, if you wanted to do something with others, you would generally find yourself slumming it at the local recreation center. That's what this game brings you back to, spending time with strangers doing social things. And this way you don't have to worry about seeing that old guy naked in the locker rooms, or wonder if you might get kidnapped by that creepy guy with the trenchcoat. Not to mention the wide variety of games for everyone: Charades for those times when your word is Robin Hood, and everyone in the room keeps guessing a camel because you're awful at drawing; Paintball, for all those times you wanted to know how poorly you'd do in a real fps; Ping Pong, because it wasn't frustrating enough in real life so now you get to chase a ping pong ball accross two floors; Dodgeball, so you can experience what it was like to be the fat kid during PE. Now the servers don't seem to have the greatest connection sometimes people's voices might lag, or they'll slowly start to drift off into the sky, but this is the new generation of chat rooms, and it looks... very positive. With vr you get this extra level of communication, though rudimentary, there's real body language being transmitted, and that's honestly very cool with such a positive community in this currently. This is the Wii sports of VR, as in, this game by itself, makes your purchase feel worth it.

								Rec Room has been one of my top 3 games to play in VR ever since I got my HTC Vive!  For the price, you get a heft amount of content plus I love the incentives you have for coming back such as the allure of new items.  I noticed the locker room area also has some renovations coming soon so it's nice to see the devs adding more content.  The basic gist of the game is that you have a few main areas: Your dorm room is where you customize your character and just fool around getting used to the controls and such.  The locker room is the lobby of sorts where people from around the world congregate and fool around with basketballs, frisbees, darts, ping pong, punching dummies, dodgeballs, boomboxes, etc.  You can talk to people if you like and it's nice to see features such as being able to mute yourself and others just in case things get a bit annoying.  The other areas are the main meat of the game which are the Rec Room activities.  You've got various things to choose from: dodgeball, disc golf, 3D charades, paintball, shield soccer, and paddle ball.  My favorite activities to play are dodgeball and paintball, they are both great for a workout because of all the dodging and ducking you'll be doing!  The games themselves, from what I've seen, typically have very friendly and fun people playing them so there's no need to feel socially anxious about joining a game with strangers.  There is one last area which was recently added and it's a private lounge which you can relax in alone or you can invite friends and other players.  Inside the private lounge, you'll find a dart board, ping pong table, dice, a card table, a boombox, a conference room complete with whiteboards, and a 3D charades stage.All in all, this is one of the best examples I've played as far as AAA virtual reality games are concerned because the polish and attention to detail is high with Rec Room and the replay value is very high especially due to the social aspect of it since it's online.  If you have a VR headset, Rec Room needs to be in your library!Checkout my playthrough of a couple Rec Room games!

Early Access Review
								A few par-for-the-course early access bugs notwithstanding, this is an impressively polished and super fun social VR title! The environments, soundtrack, and the aesthetic of the avatars all set a playful and welcoming tone. Fist bumping to party up with others is charmingly intuitive, and who doesn't love high fives with confetti?! The integration of equipable video cameras is a clever addition to a social space like this, adding another way to interact beyond playing the game modes proper or tossing around toys.Of the games currently included, my favorite is paddle ball. It's ridiculously fun getting into a heated one-on-one volley exchange. Make sure you're secure with your chaperone and have cleared plenty of space for exuberant swinging, as the matches do get intense!The only issues I've encountered so far have been a bit of judder in the lobby occasionally, and some minor glitchy behavior related to avatar customization. The sports themselves run remarkably solid though, with no noticeable lag or major physics weirdness. Voice chat is clear and loud, perhaps working *too* well with more boisterous chatters in the area, but individuals can thankfully be muted. Teleportation is nicely implemented, with an aiming arch and helpful preview of your avatar's warp location.If you have a Vive, don't hesitate to give this one a go. At its current price of FREE you are getting an incredible value. I'd have unquestionably thrown some cash towards this, and still would as it becomes more robust with time.

								This game is where I've spent most of my VR time as of writing this review, the best way to describe it is as a YMCA in VR.  You can drop in and out at any time with friends or other internet strangers to play painball, shrades, or even a mocking but very adorable and amusing dungeon crawler.  The games are very fun with controls that feel natural and intuitive (with the Vive Controllers) as well as the graphics being very stylized so that the entire game is easy on your hardware, but also easy on your eyes and good looking.All the games within Rec-Room require very little playable space, with the exception of the "shield soccer" minigame where you may want more space to avoid punching your walls or furniture.Overall, its free, its fun, its a great way to meet other people with VR hardware, its multi-platform (supporting both the Vive and Rift, which is always a great thing to see, since limiting the VR market and making games headset or OS exclusive is the worst thing for VR right now) and it's got a taste of a wide variety of VR experiences.

								When I first got the Vive, I pretty much downloaded every free game available. I tried most of them out, but needless to say,Rec Room earned a special place in my list of favourite VR games. I've had as much fun derping around in the lobby and doing virtual bottle flip challenges with people as I had playing the actual games. VR Paintball? Heck yes! Zero-G ball tennis? Awesome! Frisbee golfing? Totally! Throwing pointy darts at eachother? Of course!Positive points: Multiplayer Lobby shenanigans Creative gamemodes Friendly family-based design FreeNegative points: Weird body physics sometimes Few gamemodes Teleport ability during Paintball and DodgeballPeople say this is a must-have for any Vive owner, and to be honest, they are totally right. The friendly social vibe that hangs around this game makes me see it more of a place to be, than a program to start up.

								Rec Room is easily the most fun I've had with my Vive so far, which is espicially impressive consdering that it's free. The game modes are well done, and there's lots of little things to love. The video camera, for instance, is a great idea. You can pick it up in game and use it to record videos to your computer, using it just like a real handheld video camera. I also have to say I really love the locker room. The locker room is the area where you choose which game mode to play, but it doubles as a lobby/sandbox area. There's dodgeballs, darts, water bottles, and much more. It's amazing how much it can be to just mess around in there with strangers. Speaking of strangers, Rec Room is a great place to meet people. I imagine that a lot of people are like me, and know either none or very few people that also have a Vive. I've made a few friends playing Rec Room that I can now go and play other VR games with, thanks to it's social design. I have only run into the rare glitch, and nothing too bad so far. The main thing that bugs me about it is that the game needs more content. For example, paintball is great but it only has one map and two game modes (team deathmatch and capture the flag). More maps is a must but it would also be nice to maybe see a free for all mode or others. There are a few other matters of polish and quality of life that could be addressed also. For example, between matches in paintball a single player can start the next match almost immedietly after the first without any sort of vote from other players. At the very least they should impliment a minimum time between matches, even if it's fairly short. I also think it should pop up a box asking you if you want your mic to be always on or push to talk when you play for the first time. Few people expect their mic to be hot all the time by default.Overall, great game, but I want more stuff! I wouldn't mind paying for some DLC if it had good content.

								Rec Room is a mystery to me. It is a fantastic game with a ton of polish and is updated relatively often... yet it's free... like really free. Not free to play that gets you hooked early on and then you hit a wall of extreme difficulty or build timers or anything like that. It's just straight up free. How the Hell do these guys make money?Anyhow, it's great. Packed full of so many sports, from frisbee golf, to paintball, to dodgeball, or paddle ball, and it even has charades which is surprisingly fun and addictive with friends. The also added in a dungeon crawler game to it which is extremely difficult and requires some solid teamwork to get through. Then there's plenty of mini-games and such in the locker room area and really shows a cool social element to the game as you can chat with people and party up by fist-bumping other players. Players gain XP throughout all events and you unlock loot boxes that you actually get to unpack and they unlock new clothing and accesories to where on your avatar. 5/5 Seriously, how/why is this amazing game free?

								Rec Room is easily one of if not the most genuinely fun and entertaining VR experiences currently available, and it's totally free. Whether you just want to hang out in the locker room to shoot hoops and chat or play one of the intuitive and polished games, there's always something fun to do. The games are great and daily challenges will motivate you to try new things. The open-mic social sandbox environment makes for the real possibility of mic abusers and griefing, but the simple tools for managing offenders (muting, ghosting, votekick) make it almost a non-issue, and I tend to find myself making new friends more often than adding people to my ignore list. The devs seem committed to improving the game and adding more content on a regular basis, and I'm excited to see where this experiment goes!

Early Access Review
								Fantastic. This should be worth _at least_ 5$ just for the paintball. This game is basically Wii Sports: VR:, and thats a ton more fun than it sounds. You can play paintball and other games you will try and never play again, because paintball is so good. Its fun, tactical, and has a great community (for the most part) of adults and children alike having a blast. The game is a perfect fit for VR: Grabbing guns, balls, and cameras with your Vive or Oculus hand controllers (Wands and Touch respectivly) feels very responsive and intuitive. Items are also importance-sensitive: Meaning, you either need to constantly hold down the grab button (balls, markers, etc.) or just press once and let it stick (guns), which is a fantastic way to do things. The dorm room and leveling systems are icing on the painball-flavored cake: Its a cool personal space to relax before heading off. Even the menu is awesome: Just look to your left hand as if checking ones watch, and there you go. Menu, always at the ready. In short, this game is an absolute steal for the low, low price of nothing, and a true VR must have. A note, though: The default Oculus touch setup is insufficent here: You can turn with the thumbsticks, but you often get too caught up in the action to remember to turn. The 2 camera 360 or 3 camera roomscale is strongly advised.(Update)Now that both Quest for the Golden Trophy and Rise of the Jumbotron have come out, theres still zero excuse to not get this game. If this game is a mmo (which it kinda is) these activities are the raids: They are cooperative, PVE campaigns that are extremely difficult and provide a great challenge to those who are already acclimated to VR. And they are hard: These will have you progressing through rooms of enemies with basically one-shot kill potential while it takes multiple well placed shots on the players part to down them, and tricky (and sometimes straight unfair) enemy spawning makes these seriously hard, even with a well-communicating team. They will have you ducking, getting on your knees, crawling, dodging, and generally moving to avoid being hit, providing a real physical challenge. Unlike most VR shooters, which slow down time (Space Pirate Trainer, Superhot VR) or slow down bullets when close (Robo Recall), these projectiles move at a fast clip, fire frequently, and are generally more deadly (downing in one shot) than the other games. Get some friends or play with randos and cooperate to win: Theres sweet loot for those who make it. I personally recommend Jumbotron over Golden Trophy, just because guns are easier use than bows, making deaths less frustrating, and because it has better level design overall. In conclusion, these two PVE expansions just make getting this game even more worthwhile.
